trivia: The computer mouse was invented by Douglas Engelbart in 1964 and was originally made of wood.
The QWERTY keyboard layout was designed in the 1870s for typewriters and is still used for most computers today.
The word 'data' is the plural of 'datum', which means a single piece of information.
Early computer monitors were monochrome and could only display one color, usually green or amber.
The first microprocessor, the Intel 4004, was released in 1971 and could execute 60,000 operations per second.
RAM stands for Random Access Memory and is used for temporary data storage while a computer is running.
The internet was originally called ARPANET and was developed by the U.S. Department of Defense in the late 1960s.
Software refers to the programs and operating information used by a computer, as opposed to the physical hardware.
The word 'algorithm' comes from the name of Persian mathematician Al-Khwarizmi, who lived in the 9th century.
Cache memory is a small-sized type of volatile computer memory that provides high-speed data access to the processor.
A bit is the smallest unit of data in a computer, representing a binary value of 0 or 1.
A byte consists of 8 bits and is the basic unit of data storage in computers.
A chip is a small piece of semiconducting material on which an integrated circuit is embedded.
Cloud computing allows users to store and access data and programs over the internet instead of on a local computer.
A server is a computer or system that provides resources, data, services, or programs to other computers, known as clients, over a network.
A pixel is the smallest unit of a digital image or graphic that can be displayed and represented on a digital display device.
A router is a networking device that forwards data packets between computer networks.
Syntax refers to the rules that define the combinations of symbols that are considered to be correctly structured programs in a programming language.
A database is an organized collection of structured information, or data, typically stored electronically in a computer system.
A system is a set of interacting or interdependent components forming an integrated whole.
A network is a group of two or more computer systems linked together to share resources and information.
Input refers to data or signals entered into a computer for processing.
Output is the information produced by a computer after processing input data.
Security in information systems refers to the protection of data and systems from unauthorized access and threats.
An audit in information systems is an examination of controls within an organization's IT infrastructure.
A backup is a copy of data stored separately to protect against loss or damage.
Encryption is the process of converting information or data into a code to prevent unauthorized access.
A firewall is a network security device that monitors and filters incoming and outgoing network traffic based on security rules.
Malware is software designed to disrupt, damage, or gain unauthorized access to computer systems.
Phishing is a cyberattack that uses disguised emails to trick recipients into revealing personal information.
A domain is a unique name that identifies a website on the internet.
A compiler is a program that translates source code written in a programming language into machine code.
Debugging is the process of finding and fixing errors or bugs in software code.
An interface is a shared boundary across which two or more separate components of a computer system exchange information.
Virtualization allows multiple operating systems to run on a single physical machine.
Bandwidth is the maximum rate of data transfer across a given path in a network.
A protocol is a set of rules governing the exchange or transmission of data between devices.
A token is a piece of data used in authentication and authorization processes in information systems.
A portal is a website or service that offers a broad array of resources and services, such as email, forums, and search engines.
A spreadsheet is a digital worksheet used for organizing, analyzing, and storing data in tabular form.
A dashboard is a user interface that organizes and presents information in an easy-to-read format.
Logic in computing refers to the use of reasoning to perform operations and solve problems.
A query is a request for information from a database.
An archive is a collection of historical records and documents stored digitally for long-term preservation.
LAN stands for Local Area Network, a network that connects computers within a limited area such as a building.
WAN stands for Wide Area Network, a network that covers a broad area such as a city, country, or even global connections.
Ethernet is a widely used technology for local area networks, enabling devices to communicate via wired connections.
Cloud computing delivers computing services over the internet, including storage, processing, and software.
AI stands for Artificial Intelligence, which enables machines to mimic human intelligence and perform tasks.
Machine learning is a branch of AI that allows computers to learn from data and improve over time without being explicitly programmed.
Blockchain is a distributed ledger technology that securely records transactions across many computers.
Virtual reality is a simulated experience that can be similar to or completely different from the real world.
Authentication is the process of verifying the identity of a user or device.
Authorization determines what resources a user or device can access in an information system.
SSD stands for Solid State Drive, a type of storage device that uses flash memory and is faster than traditional hard drives.
HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language and is the standard language for creating web pages.
URL stands for Uniform Resource Locator and is the address used to access resources on the internet.
Open source software is software whose source code is available for modification or enhancement by anyone.
Binary is a base-2 numeral system used by computers, consisting of only 0s and 1s.
A password is a secret word or phrase used to authenticate access to a computer system or service.
A cookie is a small piece of data stored on the user's computer by a web browser while browsing a website.
A script is a set of instructions written in a programming language to automate tasks.
A function is a block of organized, reusable code that performs a single action in programming.
An object is a data structure in programming that contains properties and methods.
A class is a blueprint for creating objects in object-oriented programming.
An array is a data structure that can hold multiple values, typically of the same type, in programming.
A stack is a data structure that follows the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle.
A queue is a data structure that follows the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle.
An encryption key is a piece of information used in cryptography to encrypt and decrypt data.
A processor core is an individual processing unit within a computer's CPU.
The motherboard is the main circuit board of a computer, connecting all components together.
An operating system is system software that manages computer hardware, software resources, and provides common services.
